Tweet: Arjuna said: "O Lord, by Your grace, You have revealed to me the supreme secret, known as the inner Self. By Your words, my delusion has been dispelled."
"I had heard from You in detail about the creation and dissolution of beings, and also about Your imperishable greatness, O lotus-eyed one."
"Thus, O Lord of the universe, I have understood You as You are. Now I wish to see Your divine form, O Supreme Person."
"If You think it is possible for me to see Your form, O Lord, O master of Yoga, then please show me Your imperishable Self."
The Lord said: "O Partha, behold My forms, hundreds and thousands, of diverse kinds, divine, and of many colors and shapes."
"See the Adityas, the Vasus, the Rudras, the Ashwins, and the Maruts. And, O descendant of Bharata, see many other wondrous things that you have never seen before."
"Behold this universe, O Gudakesha, all that moves and is immovable, existing in one place, in My body. And whatever else you wish to see, see it here."
"You cannot see Me with these eyes of yours. I give you divine vision. Now see My divine Yoga."
Sanjaya said: "After speaking thus, O King, the great Lord of Yoga, Hari, showed Arjuna His supreme, divine form."
“With countless mouths and eyes, with countless wondrous sights, adorned with countless divine ornaments, with countless raised weapons.”
"Wearing divine garlands and garments, anointed with divine perfumes, a divine being, wondrous in every way, infinite and with faces everywhere.  "
"If the radiance of a thousand suns were to rise all at once, it might resemble the glory of the great-souled One."
"Then, in the body of that Lord of gods, the Pandava saw the entire universe divided into many parts, as if it were all in one place."
"Seeing this, Arjuna was filled with wonder, his hair stood on end, and, bowing his head in reverence, with folded hands, he spoke to the Lord."
Arjuna said: "O Lord, I see all the gods in Your body, and all the assemblies of different beings. I see Brahma, Shiva, and the sages seated on lotus thrones, and all the divine snakes."
"O Lord of the universe, I see you with many arms, bellies, mouths, and eyes, Your form is infinite, without beginning, middle, or end. I see you everywhere, O universal form!"
“I see you adorned with a crown, wielding a mace and disk, dazzling with brilliance everywhere. I see you, inconceivable, blazing with the brilliance of a million suns, impossible to behold."

"You are the imperishable, the ultimate truth to be known. You are the supreme refuge of this universe. You are the imperishable, the eternal guardian of Dharma. You are the Supreme Person, as I understand You."

“I see you, without beginning, middle, or end, with infinite energy, with infinite arms, with eyes like the sun and moon, your face blazing like a thousand suns, burning this universe with your own brilliance.”
“You fill this space between heaven and earth, and every direction. O great soul, seeing your wondrous, terrible form, these three worlds are trembling.”
“Some of these gods, terrified, are entering your body, bowing and praising you. The great sages and Siddhas, saying, ‘Peace! Peace!’, are praising you with abundant hymns.”
“The Rudras, Adityas, Vasus, Sadhyas, Vishvedevas, Ashwins, Maruts, Ushmapas, Gandharvas, Yakshas, Asuras, and Siddhas, all are astonished to see you.”
“Seeing your great form, with many mouths, eyes, arms, legs, bellies, and terrible fangs, I, along with the rest of the world, am terrified.”
"O Vishnu, seeing your form, which touches the sky, is blazing with many colors, has a wide mouth, and has bright, large eyes, my heart is trembling, and I find no courage or composure."
"Seeing your terrible mouths, which resemble the fires of death,  I don't know the directions, I find no peace. Please be merciful, O Lord, O dweller in the universe."
"All the sons of Dhritarashtra, along with the armies of kings, and Bhishma, Drona, Karna, the son of a charioteer, and all the rest of our warriors, are entering your mighty mouth."
"They are rushing into your mouths, which are terrible, with sharp fangs. Some are seen stuck between your teeth, with their limbs crushed."
“Just as many rivers rush towards the ocean with their currents, so these heroes of the human world are rushing into your blazing mouths."
“Just as moths rush into a blazing fire for their destruction, even so these beings are rushing with great speed into your mouths for their destruction.”
“O Vishnu, you are licking up all beings with your blazing mouths. Your fierce radiance fills the entire universe.  And your effulgence is burning the whole world.”
“Please tell me who You are, O awesome one.  I bow to You, O god, please be merciful. I want to know You, the primordial one. For I do not know the extent of your power."
The Lord said: "I am Time, the destroyer of all things, come to annihilate these worlds.  Even without you, all the warriors standing in opposing armies would not survive."
"Therefore, stand up and gain glory. Conquer your enemies and enjoy a prosperous kingdom. All these warriors have already been slain by Me. You are merely an instrument, O Savyasachi."
“Drona, Bhishma, Jayadratha, Karna, and all the other mighty warriors, I have already slain them. Fight without fear, and you shall conquer your enemies in battle.”
Sanjaya said: “Hearing these words of Keshava, Arjuna, crowned with a diadem,  bowed his head and, trembling, spoke to Krishna in a choked voice, bowing again and again.”
Arjuna said: "O Hrishikesha, the world rejoices and is attracted by your fame. The demons are terrified, the directions tremble, and all the Siddhas bow down to you."

“O great soul, why should not all beings bow down to you, who are greater than Brahma himself, the primeval creator? You are infinite, O Lord of the universe, the abode of all beings, the imperishable, and the ultimate reality beyond existence and non-existence.”

“You are the primordial god, the original Person, the ancient one. You are the supreme refuge of this universe. You are the knower and the known, the supreme abode, and the universe is pervaded by You, who are infinite in form.”
"You are the wind, Yama, fire, Varuna, the moon, Prajapati, and Brahma, the grandsire.  I bow to you a thousand times, and again and again, I bow to you."
"I bow to you from the front, from the back, from all sides, and everywhere. You are infinite in power, with unyielding might. You are all, and you pervade all. Therefore, you are all."
“Out of familiarity, I have spoken to you as, ‘O Krishna, O Yadava, O friend,’ out of ignorance of your greatness, or perhaps out of love.  “

"And if I have treated you lightly, by speaking jestingly, or in matters of recreation, beds, seats, or food, or if I have at any time been disrespectful in your presence, O Achyuta, then forgive me, O immeasurable one."
"You are the father of the movable and immovable world.  You are the most venerable, the greatest teacher. There is no one equal to you, nor is there anyone more powerful in the three worlds."

“Therefore, I bow down to you, I offer myself to you, I appease you, the most worshipful Lord. Like a father to his son, a friend to his friend, a beloved to his beloved, O god, you are worthy of being endured. ”
“Seeing your form, I am overcome with joy and fear, my mind is troubled. Please, O god, show me your form again.  Be merciful, O Lord of the universe.”
"I wish to see you again, adorned with a crown, holding a mace and a disk, in that same four-armed form.  O universal form, O thousand-armed one, please appear in that form.”

The Lord said: “O Arjuna, because you are devoted, I have shown you this supreme form, emerging from My Yoga.  This radiant, infinite, primordial universe has never been seen before by anyone other than you."
“No one in this world, O best of the Kurus, can see Me in this form, not through the study of the Vedas, not by sacrifices, not by charity, not by austerities, not through any other action.”
"Don’t be distressed, don’t be bewildered. Seeing this terrible form of Mine,  be fearless, be happy.  See Me again in this very form.”
Sanjaya said: “Having said this to Arjuna, Vasudeva again showed him His own form.  And, resuming His gentle form, the great soul reassured Arjuna, who was frightened."
Arjuna said: "Seeing your gentle human form, O Janardana, my mind is now composed and I have returned to my natural state."
The Lord said: "This form of Mine, which you have seen, is very difficult to see. Even the gods always desire to see this form.”
"I cannot be seen by the Vedas, not by austerities, not by charity, not by sacrifices.  You have seen Me in this form as I am."
“O Arjuna, O chastiser of the enemy, I can be known, seen in My true nature, and entered into only by unalloyed devotion.”
"He who performs actions for My sake, who is devoted to Me, who is free from attachment, who is without hatred towards all beings, he comes to Me, O Pandava."
